Saying we can't raise the minimum wage until we're out of this pandemic and our economy is stronger is a false argument.

Q: What can the federal government do to support voting rights around the country? 

A: We must pass the John Lewis Voting Rights Act. We can, and must extend some the voting rights we enjoy in MD to the rest of our 50 states and territories.

Q: I am concerned about the unfinished Purple Line and when it will be complete. 
 
A: I will make sure federal dollars are not in jeopardy. I have written letters to the Governor about this issue and will make sure it's a top priority in the next infrastructure package.

Q: Tell me about relief for small businesses? 

A: We have streamlined and simplified access to aide in small business support. We've improved programs such as PPP and expanded eligibility categories. We have set aside money for community banks and minority lending institutions.

Q: How are you making our schools safe? 

A: In our Relief Package, we secured $128.5 billion in grants for elementary and secondary school reopening and stabilization. We will do everything we can to re-open safely.

Q: Why was it important to pass the Equality Act today? 

A: Let’s be clear, regardless of your sexual or gender orientation: all Americans should be treated equally and with dignity. I was proud to vote for this bill today.

Q: What are your top priorities on the Veterans Affairs Committee? 

A: In the short term, I will ensure our Veterans are getting their benefits through the relief package. Veterans need direct cash assistance and we must ensure our senior Veterans get vaccinated.

Q: How will you address equity issues in the vaccine rollout? 

A: MD's Equity Task Force will ensure we combat the digital divide and bring the vaccine to our communities instead of making communities of color seek the vaccine. It’s time to meet folks where they are.

Countering the intent of Title IX undermines female competitors and limits their access to opportunity via scholarships etc. If our laws do not recognize the biological difference between men and women, female athletes will be the ones to suffer the consequences. (4/4)

Allowing transgender individuals to compete in women’s sports is unfair, unsafe, and completely undermines the intent of Title IX in the first place. As the father of three girls involved in wrestling, I want them to be able to compete on a level playing field. (3/4)

There is no doubt that Title IX has given female athletes lifechanging opportunities, yet today, the House passed H.R. 5, the Equality Act, which would withhold federal funding from any college or university that does not allow biological men to compete in women's sports. (2/4)

Title IX was passed to protect women from sex discrimination in all federally funded school programs. Since then, there has been a 545% increase in the number of women playing college sports, and athletics scholarships have opened countless doors for female athletes. (1/4)

When finding decent employment became difficult due to racist restrictions, the Black community came together to push forth change and demand decency in order the live a decent life.

After getting past the racist hiring practices, Black workers still faced mistreatment, often relegated to the hottest and most dangerous work zones at Hoover Dam. Black and Brown people migrated to Nevada during this time, after the Great Depression for work.

Colored Citizens Labor and Protective Association of Las Vegas, which was later supported by William Pickens of the NAACP, got 24 African Americans work at the Hoover Dam out of the 200k workers employed.

When the lowest wage workers do better, everyone does better. Raising the minimum wage will help economies grow and communities flourish. Don't tell me we can't afford to raise the minimum wage. We can't afford NOT to.

An increase in the minimum wage would also be incredibly beneficial to Black and Brown workers, who often feel the greatest brunt of our nation's growing inequality. Raising the minimum wage is a social justice issue.

The current pandemic has further revealed how so many of these workers are just one missed paycheck away from financial ruin. An increase in the minimum wage to $15 an hour would give 27 million workers a raise, and help them become more financially secure.

We need to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour. The federal minimum wage has been stuck at $7.25 for over a decade, and more and more Americans are living paycheck to paycheck largely because of this.

14/ So I scroll through Twitter until I find someone who tweeted the moment.  (You know, where you see the C-SPAN screen shot of the moment the count hits 218).  And there they are, front and center, surrounded by a bunch of folks who are excited about having a cool job. /fin

13/ Anyway, a couple hours later, we are walking home and swapping stories about their day and all the stories they can't wait to tell their friends & my daughter asks me why I asked her to go to the well.
12/ And I got to share it with my daughter.

11/ Then the count hits 218 and - for the 2nd time in my Congressional career - the gallery erupts.  This time with a cheer of "Si se puede!  Si se puede!".  Again, we do the tears, goofy fistbumps and share a moment of joy, pride, humility and too many other emotions to mention.

10/ So I vote and then tell my daughter & her friend to go down and mingle in "the well" by the dais.  I chat with colleagues.  At one point, @SpeakerPelosi says hello to them (she always takes time for kids).  They are star-struck.

9/ As we walk in I look up (remember, I'm a crafty veteran by now) and notice the gallery is packed for the 2nd time in my Congressional career, this time with a lot of folks who's skin looks a bit browner than mine.

8/ Act II.  1 month later.  My daughter is visiting with a friend.  That day we were voting to pass the Dream and Promise Act - major immigration reform, providing a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented Americans.  So I brought them to the floor for the vote.

7/ And then do the same with a lot of other members.  None of us wanted to leave the floor.  The gallery is cheering for us, we're cheering for them, all of us are humbled by the moment.  Anyway, end of Act I.

6/ I know my eyes are moist and as I look down on the floor I see @SpanbergerVA07.  We exchange one of those I'm-not-crying-you're-crying-oh-let's-be-honest-we're-both-crying-I-am-so-proud-to-have-this-job looks.   As one does in such moments.

5/ And it hits me how important this job is.  How many lives depend on what we do.  And I'm getting emotional.  I give them all the fist bumps and whatever goofy signals I can muster.  One love.  People get ready.  I get choked up.

4/ I hadn't noticed anyone was in the gallery before that moment. I hadn't looked up because the gallery is usually empty.  But it was packed.  Lots of pink.  Lots of rainbows.  More importantly, lots of lives directly affected by that vote.  Cheering & crying tears of joy.

3/ So I went to the floor, voted yes and then spent time chatting with colleagues on the floor.  And suddenly the gallery (the seats above the floor) erupted with cheers.  Because we'd just hit the magic 218 that ensured the bill would pass.
2/ Intuitively, of course we know some are more meaningful.  But the feedback is usually delayed.  My first experience of anything different was the vote on the #EqualityAct in the 116th.

1/ So one of the weirder things about this job is that all votes "feel" the same.  Lots of debate, drama, press before & after (some) votes, but the process of pressing yay or nay is the same on a post office renaming as it is on a $5T appropriation.

13. Politically speaking, losers always cry louder than winners cheer.  So this is a way to ease that pain and accelerate the transition.   And on balance, a good thing.  You may now return to your regularly scheduled programming.  /fin

12. The devil is of course in the details.  And it's purely a transitional policy.  But the hardest political challenge with the clean energy transition is how to deal with the wealth transfer from energy producers to consumers.
11. Thus, all economic actors are equivalently situated, but we've shut down a polluting source of expensive energy to free up space for cleaner, cheaper sources to come on line.
10. The securitization essentially creates a bond issuance that pays down that capital per contract, but spreads the cost to consumers (ideally) over the same time period as the prior capital.
9. This is goofy.  It's complicated.  It 'taint right.  But it is the existing law, and we must play the cards we are dealt.  Enter  securitization.

8. In other words, a big rate spike that will be blamed on coal plant retirement but is actually the result of a contractual obligation that prevents them from writing down that investment (as players in the unregulated world must do when their assets can no longer compete.)

7. This creates a challenge for utility regulators because if those plants were shut down in response to economic, competitive forces, all that non-amortized capital would be "brought forward" and charged to the next year's kWh revenue, rather than being spread out over time.
6. But if you'll accept the simplification, you now have plants that are earning revenue per kWh in excess of what is available from cleaner sources, but they haven't yet amortized all their capital.
5. (I say sort of because even if they are still earning regulated rates, they are connected to grids with actors who are not and affect supply/demand balances.  Too much detail to go into there...)

4. The problem arises when those plants are no longer economic and can't compete in a deregulated electric grid.  Much of the nations' coal fleet is - shall we say - half-pregnant with deregulation.  Built in one paradigm, but operating (sort of) in another.

3. Whatever one thinks of that approach, as a matter of contract law, if you invested the capital to build the plant (and subsequent upgrades) subject to that understanding, you have a reasonable expectation to earn the return.

2. To understand why this is necessary, you need to understand that under the traditional regulated utility construct, a utility invests capital in exchange for a guaranteed rate of return, earned through kWh sales.

I introduced the BRIDGE Act to provide flexible funding to states and tribal governments to expand broadband access. This is a fix to a problem that existed long before COVID-19 but is especially critical now to meet remote learning needs during the pandemic.

However, the digital divide that impacts both rural and historically underserved communities took double the toll on their student body. They are still struggling to connect students to broadband internet to access remote learning.
The president of Fort Lewis College, Tom Stritikus, was able to establish a testing program on campus and continue to deliver meals to students in part because of early relief efforts.

Fort Lewis Colorado in Durango is an affordable, minority serving institution where 40% of students belong to tribes. Last year, Fort Lewis closed in person classes and moved instruction online overnight.

This story is all too common in Colorado and around the country. I introduced the American Family Act to expand the Child Tax Credit and give working families like Pauline’s a tax cut of $3,000 per child or $3,600 per child under age 6, paid monthly, to help afford expenses.

At a child care roundtable in Eagle County, I heard from parents like Pauline, a single mother, who along with many of her friends and neighbors struggled to afford childcare and health insurance during the pandemic.

.@ShennaBellows during today’s hearing: “#HR1 is well-crafted to help states like Maine meet the challenges of our time. The states need help from Congress to effectively and efficiently implement modernization to improve security and accessibility…”

.@ProfGuyCharles: “#HR1 would be the most transformative civil rights statute passed by Congress since the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act. #HR1 reflects and articulates a very simple principle: voting is a fundamental right of American citizenship...”

.@ProfGuyCharles during today’s hearing: “…For too many American citizens, the right to vote remains ephemeral even in federal elections and the availability of the right remains far too contingent upon the capricious whims of political actors…”

.@ShennaBellows on the #ForThePeople Act: "#HR1 is critical because it eliminates barriers and lifts up the voices of ordinary people in our democracy. #HR1 builds upon tried and true best practices already proven to work in the states, places like Maine and across the country."

.@ShennaBellows/@MESecOfState: “For too many Americans across the country, participation in politics and service in elected office is out of reach -a privilege reserved for the wealthy instead of the constitutional right guaranteed in our beloved Constitution and Bill of Rights.”

.@ProfGuyCharles/@DukeLaw: "Congress has the ability, and the responsibility, to identify the best set of practices to make voting and democratic participation accessible to all, particularly to the most vulnerable members of our political community."
"#HR1 has broad-based and bipartisan support for its provisions to empower voters and protect our free and fair and safe elections.”
.@StaceyAbrams on the #ForThePeople Act: “However, the provisions of #HR1 would create a uniform foundation for democracy in America that does not rely on geography.”

.@StaceyAbrams: “Georgia stands as a singular example of the legislative whiplash from defending the integrity of elections in November and January to these naked attempts to erect new hurdles for voters of color, young voters, poor voters and other marginalized communities...”
.@StaceyAbrams: "However, the truth is this: Congress must to act boldly and quickly to safeguard, strengthen and preserve our democracy."
